Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset snug against my ear, the script for our new service open in front of me. My job as a telemarketer was clear: follow the script, handle objections, and keep the call moving. But today, the calls were different. Prospects kept asking detailed technical questions—questions the script only half-answered. I could sense their confusion, their need for honest, thorough information. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Stick to the script. Don’t get sidetracked.”

But as a Christian, I felt a tug in my heart. I believed in honesty, in treating others as I’d want to be treated. Was it right to dodge their questions, to gloss over details just to make a sale? Each time I redirected a caller back to the script, guilt gnawed at me. I wanted to help them understand, to be truthful, but the pressure to perform, to meet my quota, pressed down on me. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, my next call waiting, as I wrestled with what I should do.
